base_frequency_hint: Fundamental frequency of your bamboo (A4 = 440 Hz, D4 = 293.66 Hz, G4 = 392 Hz)
inner_diameter_hint: Internal bore diameter of the flute
build_scale: Build Your Scale - Hole by Hole
footer: Crafted with care for flute makers worldwide üåø

all_holes_configured: ‚úì All holes configured! The table below shows your custom scale.
algo_xiao_intro: The Sanfen Sunyi (‰∏âÂàÜÊçüÁõäÊ≥ï) is an ancient Chinese mathematical method for calculating musical intervals, perfect for crafting Xiao flutes. This method creates beautiful pentatonic scales by alternating between adding and subtracting thirds.
algo_xiao_how_1: Start with the base frequency of your bamboo (the fundamental note)
algo_xiao_how_2: San Fen Sun Yi (‰∏âÂàÜÊçü‰∏Ä): "Divide into three parts, lose one" - multiply frequency by 3/2 (perfect fifth up)
algo_xiao_how_3: San Fen Yi Yi (‰∏âÂàÜÁõä‰∏Ä): "Divide into three parts, gain one" - multiply frequency by 4/3 (perfect fourth up)
algo_xiao_how_4: For each hole, you can choose the next interval to create your desired scale
algo_xiao_how_5: Includes acoustic correction based on bore diameter and temperature
algo_calc_details_intro: The effective length for each note is calculated as:
algo_xiao_calc_1: Speed of sound: v = 331.3 + 0.606 √ó T (m/s) where T is temperature in ¬∞C
algo_xiao_calc_4: Hole position: Position = L_eff - Œ¥ (from blowing edge)
algo_empirical_intro: Important: This calculator provides theoretical positions, but flute making requires an empirical approach:
algo_empirical_1: Start small: Begin by drilling holes smaller than calculated
algo_empirical_2: Test and adjust: Gradually enlarge each hole while testing the pitch
algo_empirical_3: Work systematically: Start from the lowest pitch (furthest hole) and move toward the highest (closest to blowing edge)
algo_empirical_4: Fine-tune: Small adjustments in hole size significantly affect pitch
algo_acoustical_intro: This method uses fundamental acoustic principles to calculate hole positions based on the speed of sound, desired frequencies, and the physical properties of the flute.
algo_acoustical_how_1: Uses the relationship: f = v / (2 √ó L) where f is frequency, v is speed of sound, L is effective length
algo_acoustical_how_2: Accounts for end corrections based on bore diameter
algo_acoustical_how_3: Considers temperature and humidity effects on sound velocity
algo_acoustical_how_4: More accurate for precise tuning requirements
algo_acoustical_calc_3: Effective length: L_eff = v / (2 √ó f) - Œ¥
algo_acoustical_calc_4: Hole position: Distance from embouchure hole
algo_benade_intro: Developed by physicist Arthur Benade, this advanced method provides highly accurate hole positions by considering the acoustic impedance and coupling between holes.
algo_benade_how_1: Accounts for hole diameter relative to bore diameter
algo_benade_how_2: Considers the acoustic mass and compliance of the air column
algo_benade_how_3: Uses the chimney height (wall thickness) in calculations
algo_benade_how_4: Most accurate method for professional instrument making
algo_benade_calc_2: Hole impedance: Z = f(d, D, t) where d=hole diameter, D=bore diameter, t=wall thickness
algo_benade_calc_3: Position correction: Adjusted based on hole coupling effects
fundamental_length_hint: Distance from blowing edge to the end
empirical_warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è Empirical method recommended: In case of hole overlap risk, you need to move the next hole up and enlarge it. This empirical approach allows adjusting the position and diameter of holes to avoid overlaps while maintaining the desired tuning.
step1_half_wave: Open at both ends | Half-wave (L_eff = c / (2 * f0))
step1_quarter_wave: Closed at one end, TSH | Quarter-wave (L_eff = c / (4 * f0))
step1_half_wave_hint: Transverse flute, Bansuri, simple open flute (max 10 holes)
step1_quarter_wave_hint: Native American double chamber flute (max 7 holes)
step1_quarter_wave_delta: Delta = TSH node displacement + end correction
step2_error_invalid_positions: The current parameters would place some holes beyond the blowing edge, which is physically impossible.
measurement_guide_lphys_desc: The physical length is the total measurable distance of your flute from end to end. This is a fundamental measurement that affects all calculations.
measurement_guide_lphys_point1: Measure from the very top edge of the embouchure hole to the bottom end of the flute
measurement_guide_lphys_point2: Use a caliper or precise ruler for accuracy (¬±1mm precision recommended)
measurement_guide_lphys_point3: For closed-end flutes, measure to the physical bottom; for open-end, to the exit opening
measurement_guide_image_lphys: Illustration: Measuring Lphys from embouchure to end
measurement_guide_dinner_desc: The inner diameter is the internal width of the flute bore. This measurement is crucial for calculating acoustic corrections.
measurement_guide_dinner_point1: Measure the inside diameter of the tube using calipers
measurement_guide_dinner_point2: Take measurements at several points and use the average for irregular bores
measurement_guide_dinner_point3: For tapered bores, measure at the section where holes will be drilled
measurement_guide_image_dinner: Illustration: Measuring inner diameter with calipers
measurement_guide_freq_desc: Measuring the actual frequencies your flute produces helps calculate effective length and end corrections with precision.
measurement_guide_freq_point1: Use a tuner app or electronic tuner to measure the fundamental frequency (all holes closed)
measurement_guide_freq_point2: Note 1: Play with normal breath pressure for the base frequency
measurement_guide_freq_point3: Note 2 (optional): Play with stronger breath to measure the upper register frequency
measurement_guide_image_freq: Illustration: Using a tuner to measure frequency
measurement_guide_tip1_desc: Small measurement errors compound through calculations. Aim for ¬±0.5mm accuracy on length measurements and ¬±0.1mm on diameter.
measurement_guide_tip2_desc: Take each measurement 2-3 times and use the average. This reduces random errors and increases reliability.
measurement_guide_tip3_desc: Temperature affects both the flute material and sound speed. Measure in conditions similar to where you'll play the flute (ideally 20-25¬∞C).
